title: How to Get a .COM Domain: Ultimate  2026 Global Guide
excerpt: Discover why the .com extension remains the global gold standard for businesses in 2026. This guide covers how to register your domain using local payment methods like M-PESA, tips for a stress-free transfer to Truehost, and how to avoid common technical errors that keep your site offline.
content:
When you think of a website, your brain might automatically add a .com at the end. It’s the original and most common type of internet address. Whether you're running a small business in Eldoret, starting a tech company in Lagos, or running a consulting firm in Johannesburg, a .com domain acts like a worldwide business card. It shows the world that you're ready to do business—not just in your local area, but around the globe.


But let's be honest: registering a domain can feel like a pain if you're working with international providers who don't get how we run our business. That’s where Truehost comes in. Here's the real scoop on why you need a .com, how to get it with the payment methods you're comfortable using, and how to steer clear of those frustrating tech problems.

In this guide, you’ll learn:

  • Why .com still dominates globally

  • How to register your .com domain with Truehost

  • How to transfer your domain safely

  • Common registrar errors and how to avoid them


1) Why .COM Still Wears the Crown

You've probably seen .co.ke, .ng, .in, and even newer ones like .shop. So, why stick with the classic?

  • a) It's What People Type: Most users have "muscle memory" for .com. If they forget your extension, they'll try .com first. If you don't own it, you're essentially handing your customers to a competitor.

  • b) Universal Trust: Whether your customer is in London, Dubai, or Mumbai, everyone knows and trusts .com. It builds instant credibility that local extensions sometimes struggle to match on the global stage.

  • c) Search Engine Juice: Google treats .com as a global player. It's the perfect choice if you want to rank well across borders without being "pigeonholed" to a single country.


2) Getting Your .COM with Truehost (The Local Way)

Gone are the days of needing a specific international credit card and a prayer to buy a domain. Truehost has localized the entire process across Kenya, Nigeria, South Africa, Uganda, and India.

  1. The Search: Head to the Truehost Domain Search. Type in your idea. Keep it short—nobody wants to type a 20-character URL.

  2. The Price (2026 Update): In 2026, Truehost remains the most affordable bridge to the global web.

    • Kenya: ~KES 1,200 for new registrations.

    • Nigeria: ~₦12,000 (often cheaper with promo codes like NEWCOM).

    • Global: Around $10.80 for the first year. (Currently, with promo code TLDBEECOM, you can get it as low as $5.85 in the US and Canada or for anyone visiting truehost.com).

  3. The Checkout: Add your domain to the cart. You'll be asked about ID Protection (WHOIS Privacy). Do it. For a small fee (around KES 400 or ₦1,500), it keeps your personal phone number and home address away from spammers and identity thieves.

  4. The Payment: Pay how you live:

    • Kenya: M-PESA (STK Push).

    • Nigeria: Paystack, Flutterwave, or Bank Transfer.

    • South Africa/India: Local cards and regional wallets.

    • Your domain goes live instantly once payment is confirmed.


3) Support That Actually Speaks Your Language

We've all been there—your site goes down on a Friday evening, and a "global" support team in a different time zone is fast asleep. Truehost is built differently:

  • 1. 24/7 Local Support: Whether it's via WhatsApp, a ticket, or a quick call, you're talking to people who understand your market and your urgency.

  • 2. No "Renewal Shock": Some providers lure you in with a $1 offer then charge you $30 to renew. Truehost's renewal rates (typically around KES 1,600 or $11.45) stay fair and transparent.

  • 3. Freebies: Many annual hosting plans (like WebHosting Pro) come with a .com domain for free for the first year; this is mostly available at Truehost.co.ke (Kenya).


4) Moving Your Existing Domain to Truehost

If you're tired of high prices or poor support elsewhere, moving to Truehost is a "safe and stress-free" process.

  • i) Unlock & Get Code: Log into your old registrar, unlock the domain, and request the EPP/Auth Code.

  • ii) Place the Order: Go to the Truehost Transfer page.

  • iii) Wait for the Magic: For .com domains, the registry takes about 5–8 business days to complete the handshake.

  • iv) Bonus: When you transfer, you usually get an extra 1-year renewal added to your current expiry date.

5) Common Issues You Might Face — And What To Do

When managing your .com domain, you won’t see complicated system codes. What you’ll experience are simple issues like delays, failed updates, or expired domains. Here’s what actually matters to you.

1. Your Website Doesn’t Go Live Immediately After Purchase

Your domain shows in your dashboard, but your website isn’t loading. This is usually domain propagation.

  • What to do: Wait up to 24 hours, clear your browser cache, and confirm your nameservers are correctly set.

2. Your Domain Transfer Is Taking Longer Than Expected

.com transfers typically take 5–8 business days.

  • What to check: Did you approve the transfer email? Is your domain unlocked? Did you enter the correct EPP/Auth code?

3. Your Domain Suddenly Stops Working

This is usually caused by expiration. If you forget to renew, your site goes offline and your emails stop. After 30 days, it enters a Redemption Period which can cost over $100 (KES 15,000) to recover.

  • What to do: Turn on Auto-Renew and keep your payment details updated.

4. You Update Nameservers but Nothing Changes

Nameserver changes take time to propagate—usually a few hours, sometimes up to 24 hours.

  • Avoid: Repeatedly changing nameservers or making multiple updates in a short period. Just wait.



The Bottom Line

Your brand deserves a home that's easy to find and impossible to forget. A .com domain gives you that global edge, and Truehost gives you the local tools to keep it running without the headache.
